Great building. Great building, saw very intersting display of Silke ? batik silk hangings. Exceptionnal and in a perfect setting.
amazing mansion. great experience to discover the palaces from Buenos Aires inside. also the restaurant bar at the entrance is excellent!!!

Loved it!. The thing that makes this museum stand out is the fact that it is situated in what was once the family home of the Errazuriz family. This gave the visit a personal feel. While you are walking round a Paris inspired mansion, built with all the finest materials from Europe, you are also looking at some of the finest works of art from Europe & the Orient too. The family had money and were big collectors! The great hall is awesome. Instructions were given that it had to be built large enough to hang 3 wonderful tapestries which had been bought before the house was started. The tasteful piped music helps you imagine the great occasions that must have been held in this room. As to the art - there are several statues by Rodin and upstairs in what was one of the bedrooms there is reportedly one of the most important collections of miniatures. In every room there is an English description of what the room was used for and/or go on an excellent guided tour for their very informative insight into the house & the art. We were tempted to list some of the amazing individual items - but say instead ..... go look for yourself - definitely worth a visit

Worth every moment spent here.. This museum is worth a visit. It is situated in a beautiful private home and has some great artwork. Every room in the house is spectacular from the large sized windows to the lovely stair cases. It is not too large and not overwhelming like most museums are. Once you come out of the museum you can check out the really beautiful garden and also have a cup of coffee at the cafe located in the garden.

Historical place in the heart of BA. This amazing manor which belonged to the Errázuriz Alvear family is now a stunning museum which exhibits incredible pieces from Argentine artists and artists around the world. It is well located and with easy access from any point in the city. The guides are very experienced in art and have a vast background on it and they are very friendly and willing to answer questions. In the central hall, you can have some coffee and rest while listening to classical music which sets the tone and creates a soothing atmosphere.
Beautiful inside and out. Gorgeous Italianate building with a cute courtyard coffee shop attached. Interesting exhibits. Worth checking out!
Ok but not worth more than 30 minute walk through. They are renovating and many display cases are empty or not in place, also no English subtitles to their labels

Beautiful building from the past. Too view religious paintings from centuries past (lighting could be enhanced) with a motor cycle collection in an European classic building is indicative of the eclectic nature of the city.
The outdoor cafe is in a beautiful setting and to observe how the local ladies 'do lunch' !

Magic place. The expositions change but the location is magnific.
The museum is located in a romantic little french castle in Libertador Avenue.
Croque Madame is a nice resto inside where you can eat french cuisine!

Not the time to go, most of this museum is closed until Oct 2012. Still had a good time and saw and Italian painting exhibit that was good, but I was sad to not see this house and its collections. The exhibits scale the walls covering up the great architectural details.

Great building. This former palace for a rich Chilean-Argentinian family is impressive. Go on a Tuesday as entry is free. Good thing for us as the exhibition from Italy was small and not very interesting. Other times may have better displays so check first

Interesting and small.. Went early (arrived at 11 am) on a Sunday to see the Italian artworks exhibition, which turn out to be a pretty complete and well-organised display. However, it takes you less than 90 minutes to see it all, so it's perfect for those who tend to get overwhelmed on large museums.The rest of this very small museum was nice; but it would not hurt if some areas of the building were freshen up. It is to be noted that by midday, there was a pretty long queue outside, as they limit the number of people allowed in the building, so arrive in the morning.

Superb Mini Museum. This was once the private home of a wealthy from the turn of last century. Marble stairs, enormous porte cochere entrance, and great examples of art nouveau, all will delight you on your visit. Definitely a Must-See...

Winning museum with a special Italian exhibition. The MNDA reopened after some renovations which were necessary to enable the opening of this special exhibit ... 600 years of Italian artworks. LOVELYOdd hours ... generally does not open until 2PM ... during school breaks, the museum opens at noon30 pesos entry fee is expected
Beautifully restored mansion. We saw a travelling exhibit of Italian art here. Do the guided tour of the palace if you can. It is well worth it. Absolutely beautiful inside.
Wonderful resturant. Inside as well as outside seating. Good service and great food. the decor is very pleasing.
Lovely expo. Really worth a visit. When we went they had a 600 years of italian paintings collection that was simply amazing. The museum's architecture is also great.
A little gem. Small but very interesting museum in what was a family house with an excellent collection of oriental works of art
Parisian Buenos Aires. Formerly the residence for a great patrician family nowadays host their impressive European art. Frick collection alla argentinean. The palace is a piece of art itself

great great great. I think the crown in all the othe museums in buenos aires a must see it will drive you to the past golden era of buenos aires
try the restaurent very nice and the food almost perfect.

A nice way to see how the other half used to live. The museum is housed in one of the grand mansions that you will hear alot about on many of the tours. This is one that you can actually get into to see how the other half of Argentine society lived. The house and a great part of the collection belonged to one family and was given to the state. It has largely been kept intact. The woodwork and the floors are outstanding. The collection of decorative arts is modest, but the the numerous tapestries are noteworthy. When you walk into the Great Hall, it just takes your breath away. As a museum director I have seen more than my fair share of decorative arts collection and this one measures up to others-albeit modestly. You have to hunt for the oriental art exhibit and the staff was not particularly helpful in pointing out what there is to see in the museum. There are no wayfinding guides. Since the cost is so low, it is certainly worth a visit.  The museum shop was interesting in that EVERYTHING was in locked cabinets and the shop staff were completely ignoring patrons who walked into the space. One was reading a newspaper and the other had her back to the shop doing some sort of paperwork and did not even look up. It is bad merchandising theory to not have items out for people to pick up and touch. It helps people make the decision to buy. We had pesos and were willing to part with some of them, but the lack of staff attention and the locked cases made our pesos stay in our pockets.
Yawn. A collection of objects donated by rich Argentinians with more money than taste or imagination decorate a large rich person's house.

Nice peek at a grand porteno mansion. The MNAD is worth a visit if you’re in the Recoleta area. This grand mansion sits just 4 blocks from the MNBA. I liked looking at the Great Hall from the second floor. The floor pattern is just so beautiful. There’s also an oriental art exhibit which you would find beyond the locker corridor (after the gift shop on the ground floor). Worth a look-see as well. No photos allowed inside.

A great setting for a nice museum. This house (yes, it was a house once upon a time) belonged to the Errazuriz Alvear family, and as you can imagine, they had a lot of money and good taste to import the materials for the house from France (even the architect was french). The collection is a bit modest if you compare it with another museums, but I believe it is quite worth it to pay a visit and enjoy the atmosphere. The outdoor cafe (Croque Madame) is really fabulous, especially if you visit in a nice sunny day as most of the seating is outside.

worth a visit. a great opportunity to peek inside one of the amazing grand old homes of BA. Not all of the house is open for visitors but what is will give an understanding of what life was like for the upper, upper, upper class of the time.

Very good museum. Beautiful mansion with lots of elements to see and admire. Great collection, including Rodin sculpture, El Greco, Manet, and Lagos, among others. English tours available on certain days.A nice little cafe also on the property.

Great Palace. Once it belonged to a rich family . NOwadays you can see not only the rooms where they lived but also there are important art pieces lice a Goya Painting. There is a nice cafe in the garden
What a House!. The art and artifacts were secondary to the mansion/architecture of the building. Go to see the house and how the rich lived 80+ years ago in a different era of B.A.
outstanding building. The building is very representative of <buenos aires at the beginning of the 20 century, and they offer excellent changing vernisages.
Mansion housing a museum. Not only a muesum, but an impressive XIXth century mansion, there are many French style mansions in town, this is one of them.
A must see on Latin amercian arts. Beautiful, affordable, and not too long. All the rooms are just like in 1800, and tour guides are very good.
Very nice. Old private home, you can see how Argentineans lived at the beginning of the XX century

Fantastic and beautiful!. I have seen two classical music concerts held at this venue. It is absolutely stunning inside- old architecture and performances of the highest standard! it is fantastic!
There is also a very good restaurant and cafe at this venue!

Lovely Mansion.. This lovely mansion was built in the early 1900's by the French architect Rene Sergent as the home of the Errazuriz Alvear family. Quoting from the brochure: "The museum's heritage consists of more than 5,000 pieces of art, including tapestries from the 15th to the 18th Centuries, as well as paintings made by El Greco, J.H. Fragonard, E. Boudin, J.B. Corot, E. Manet and sculptures made by P. Chinard, A. Rodin, A. Bourdelle, O. Zadkine and A. Lagos. Furthermore, the museum exhibits a prominent collection of European furniture from the 15th to the 19th Centuries and the most important collection of European miniature portraits conserved in Latin America." We also enjoyed champagne and a light snack at the museum's outside cafe which added to this very pleasant experience.

Beautiful. I am so glad I went to this museum. It was absolutely amazing inside and out. Since I was alone I did not go to the restaurant in front, but it looked very popular. I would definitively go to this museum while visiting BA!

Truly stunning!. As you walk through the gates and see this huge palace in front of you, you know you will enjoy your time here. The minimal fee for entry is well worth it. Walking through this house really gives you a taste of what Buenos Aires luxury was like, and looking at all the well-preserved artifacts was great also! Right outside the front door, on the grounds, there is a small, very charming cafe! Definitely recommend this place!

The building is the attraction. The attraction of this museum is the building it is housed in; an enormous and well-preserved mansion of the kind middle-class mortals don't usually get to see inside. It's amazing to get to see into the kind of palace you will be passing all the time along the streets of Recoleta. The exhibits themselves are nothing special and are mainly there as furnishings for the house.

Worth the admission price just to see the house!. Overview:This is a very elegant home that has been turned into a museum. It has a large collection of antiques on all 3 levels. The upper levels have antique furnature and the like. Many antiques are from all over the world. The bottom level has an odd assortment of antiques - miniature sowing machines, toy ships, pinball machines, etc.The House:It is truely amazing. Large doors, amazing woodwork, etc. It is worth the admission price just to see the home. Just outside in front is a small cafe.My opinion:If you have the time, then be sure to see this museum. It is a little off of the beaten path, but located in La Recoleta.
